00021 /*
00022   This file functions as the primary feedback interface for Grbl. Any outgoing data, such
00023   as the protocol status messages, feedback messages, and status reports, are stored here.
00024   For the most part, these functions primarily are called from protocol.c methods. If a
00025   different style feedback is desired (i.e. JSON), then a user can change these following
00026   methods to accomodate their needs.
00027 */
00028 
00029 #include <avr/pgmspace.h>
00030 #include "report.h"
00031 #include "print.h"
00032 #include "settings.h"
00033 #include "nuts_bolts.h"
00034 #include "gcode.h"
00035 #include "coolant_control.h"
00036 
00037 
00038 // Handles the primary confirmation protocol response for streaming interfaces and human-feedback.
00039 // For every incoming line, this method responds with an 'ok' for a successful command or an
00040 // 'error:'  to indicate some error event with the line or some critical system error during
00041 // operation. Errors events can originate from the g-code parser, settings module, or asynchronously
00042 // from a critical error, such as a triggered hard limit. Interface should always monitor for these
00043 // responses.
00044 // NOTE: In silent mode, all error codes are greater than zero.
00045 // TODO: Install silent mode to return only numeric values, primarily for GUIs.
00046 void report_status_message(uint8_t status_code)
00047 {
00048   if (status_code == 0) { // STATUS_OK
00049     printPgmString(PSTR("ok\r\n"));
00050   } else {
00051     printPgmString(PSTR("error: "));
00052     switch(status_code) {
00053       case STATUS_BAD_NUMBER_FORMAT:
00054       printPgmString(PSTR("Bad number format")); break;
00055       case STATUS_EXPECTED_COMMAND_LETTER:
00056       printPgmString(PSTR("Expected command letter")); break;
00057       case STATUS_UNSUPPORTED_STATEMENT:
00058       printPgmString(PSTR("Unsupported statement")); break;
00059       case STATUS_ARC_RADIUS_ERROR:
00060       printPgmString(PSTR("Invalid radius")); break;
00061       case STATUS_MODAL_GROUP_VIOLATION:
00062       printPgmString(PSTR("Modal group violation")); break;
00063       case STATUS_INVALID_STATEMENT:
00064       printPgmString(PSTR("Invalid statement")); break;
00065       case STATUS_SETTING_DISABLED:
00066       printPgmString(PSTR("Setting disabled")); break;
00067       case STATUS_SETTING_VALUE_NEG:
00068       printPgmString(PSTR("Value < 0.0")); break;
00069       case STATUS_SETTING_STEP_PULSE_MIN:
00070       printPgmString(PSTR("Value < 3 usec")); break;
00071       case STATUS_SETTING_READ_FAIL:
00072       printPgmString(PSTR("EEPROM read fail. Using defaults")); break;
00073       case STATUS_IDLE_ERROR:
00074       printPgmString(PSTR("Busy or queued")); break;
00075       case STATUS_ALARM_LOCK:
00076       printPgmString(PSTR("Alarm lock")); break;
00077       case STATUS_OVERFLOW:
00078       printPgmString(PSTR("Line overflow")); break;
00079     }
00080     printPgmString(PSTR("\r\n"));
00081   }
00082 }
00083 
00084 // Prints alarm messages.
00085 void report_alarm_message(int8_t alarm_code)
00086 {
00087   printPgmString(PSTR("ALARM: "));
00088   switch (alarm_code) {
00089     case ALARM_HARD_LIMIT:
00090     printPgmString(PSTR("Hard limit")); break;
00091     case ALARM_ABORT_CYCLE:
00092     printPgmString(PSTR("Abort during cycle")); break;
00093   }
00094   printPgmString(PSTR(". MPos?\r\n"));
00095   delay_ms(500); // Force delay to ensure message clears serial write buffer.
00096 }
00097 
00098 // Prints feedback messages. This serves as a centralized method to provide additional
00099 // user feedback for things that are not of the status/alarm message protocol. These are
00100 // messages such as setup warnings, switch toggling, and how to exit alarms.
00101 // NOTE: For interfaces, messages are always placed within brackets. And if silent mode
00102 // is installed, the message number codes are less than zero.
00103 // TODO: Install silence feedback messages option in settings
00104 void report_feedback_message(uint8_t message_code)
00105 {
00106   printPgmString(PSTR("["));
00107   switch(message_code) {
00108     case MESSAGE_CRITICAL_EVENT:
00109     printPgmString(PSTR("Reset to continue")); break;
00110     case MESSAGE_ALARM_LOCK:
00111     printPgmString(PSTR("'$H'|'$X' to unlock")); break;
00112     case MESSAGE_ALARM_UNLOCK:
00113     printPgmString(PSTR("Caution: Unlocked")); break;
00114     case MESSAGE_ENABLED:
00115     printPgmString(PSTR("Enabled")); break;
00116     case MESSAGE_DISABLED:
00117     printPgmString(PSTR("Disabled")); break;
00118   }
00119   printPgmString(PSTR("]\r\n"));
00120 }
00121 
00122 
00123 // Welcome message
00124 void report_init_message()
00125 {
00126   printPgmString(PSTR("\r\nGrbl " GRBL_VERSION " ['$' for help]\r\n"));
00127 }
00128 
00129 // Grbl help message
00130 void report_grbl_help() {
00131   printPgmString(PSTR("$$ (view Grbl settings)\r\n"
00132                       "$# (view # parameters)\r\n"
00133                       "$G (view parser state)\r\n"
00134                       "$N (view startup blocks)\r\n"
00135                       "$x=value (save Grbl setting)\r\n"
00136                       "$Nx=line (save startup block)\r\n"
00137                       "$C (check gcode mode)\r\n"
00138                       "$X (kill alarm lock)\r\n"
00139                       "$H (run homing cycle)\r\n"
00140                       "~ (cycle start)\r\n"
00141                       "! (feed hold)\r\n"
00142                       "? (current status)\r\n"
00143                       "ctrl-x (reset Grbl)\r\n"));
00144 }

00146 // Grbl global settings print out.
00147 // NOTE: The numbering scheme here must correlate to storing in settings.c
00148 void report_grbl_settings() {
00149   printPgmString(PSTR("$0="));
00150   printFloat(settings.steps_per_mm[X_AXIS]); printPgmString(PSTR(" (x, step/mm)\r\n$1="));
00151   printFloat(settings.steps_per_mm[Y_AXIS]); printPgmString(PSTR(" (y, step/mm)\r\n$2="));
00152   printFloat(settings.steps_per_mm[Z_AXIS]); printPgmString(PSTR(" (z, step/mm)\r\n$3="));
00153 /// 844
00154 #if (AXIS_T_TYPE == LINEAR)
00155   printFloat(settings.steps_per_mm[T_AXIS]); printPgmString(PSTR(" (u, step/mm)\r\n$3="));
00156 #else
00157   printFloat(settings.steps_per_degree[T_AXIS]); printPgmString(PSTR(" (u, step/degree)\r\n$3="));
00158 #endif
00159 
00160 /// <--
00161   printInteger(settings.pulse_microseconds); printPgmString(PSTR(" (step pulse, usec)\r\n$4="));
00162   printFloat(settings.default_feed_rate);  printPgmString(PSTR(" (default feed, mm/min)\r\n$5="));
00163   printFloat(settings.default_seek_rate);
00164  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (default seek, mm/min)\r\n$6=")); printInteger(settings.invert_mask);
00165  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (step port invert mask, int:")); print_uint8_base2(settings.invert_mask);
00166  // printPgmString(PSTR(")\r\n$7=")); printInteger(settings.stepper_idle_lock_time);
00167   printPgmString(PSTR(" (step idle delay, msec)\r\n$8=")); printFloat(settings.acceleration/(60*60)); // Convert from mm/min^2 for human readability
00168   printPgmString(PSTR(" (acceleration, mm/sec^2)\r\n$9=")); printFloat(settings.junction_deviation);
00169   printPgmString(PSTR(" (junction deviation, mm)\r\n$10=")); printFloat(settings.mm_per_arc_segment);
00170  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (arc, mm/segment)\r\n$11=")); printInteger(settings.n_arc_correction);
00171  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (n-arc correction, int)\r\n$12=")); printInteger(settings.decimal_places);
00172  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (n-decimals, int)\r\n$13=")); printInteger(bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_REPORT_INCHES));
00173  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (report inches, bool)\r\n$14=")); printInteger(bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_AUTO_START));
00174  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (auto start, bool)\r\n$15=")); printInteger(bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_INVERT_ST_ENABLE));
00175  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (invert step enable, bool)\r\n$16=")); printInteger(bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_HARD_LIMIT_ENABLE));
00176  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (hard limits, bool)\r\n$17=")); printInteger(bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_HOMING_ENABLE));
00177  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (homing cycle, bool)\r\n$18=")); printInteger(settings.homing_dir_mask);
00178  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (homing dir invert mask, int:")); print_uint8_base2(settings.homing_dir_mask);
00179  // printPgmString(PSTR(")\r\n$19=")); printFloat(settings.homing_feed_rate);
00180  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (homing feed, mm/min)\r\n$20=")); printFloat(settings.homing_seek_rate);
00181  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (homing seek, mm/min)\r\n$21=")); printInteger(settings.homing_debounce_delay);
00182  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (homing debounce, msec)\r\n$22=")); printFloat(settings.homing_pulloff);
00183  // printPgmString(PSTR(" (homing pull-off, mm)\r\n"));
00184 }

00187 // Prints gcode coordinate offset parameters
00188 void report_gcode_parameters()
00189 {

00217       else { printFloat(coord_data[i]); }

00236 
00237 // Print current gcode parser mode state
00238 void report_gcode_modes()
00239 {
00240   switch (gc.motion_mode) {
00241     case MOTION_MODE_SEEK : printPgmString(PSTR("[G0")); break;
00242     case MOTION_MODE_LINEAR : printPgmString(PSTR("[G1")); break;
00243     case MOTION_MODE_CW_ARC : printPgmString(PSTR("[G2")); break;
00244     case MOTION_MODE_CCW_ARC : printPgmString(PSTR("[G3")); break;
00245     case MOTION_MODE_CANCEL : printPgmString(PSTR("[G80")); break;
00246   }
00247 
00248   printPgmString(PSTR(" G"));
00249  // printInteger(gc.coord_select+54);
00250 
00251   if (gc.plane_axis_0 == X_AXIS) {
00252     if (gc.plane_axis_1 == Y_AXIS) { printPgmString(PSTR(" G17")); }
00253     else { printPgmString(PSTR(" G18")); }
00254   } else { printPgmString(PSTR(" G19")); }
00255 
00256   if (gc.inches_mode) { printPgmString(PSTR(" G20")); }
00257   else { printPgmString(PSTR(" G21")); }
00258 
00259   if (gc.absolute_mode) { printPgmString(PSTR(" G90")); }
00260   else { printPgmString(PSTR(" G91")); }
00261 
00262   if (gc.inverse_feed_rate_mode) { printPgmString(PSTR(" G93")); }
00263   else { printPgmString(PSTR(" G94")); }
00264 
00265   switch (gc.program_flow) {
00266     case PROGRAM_FLOW_RUNNING : printPgmString(PSTR(" M0")); break;
00267     case PROGRAM_FLOW_PAUSED : printPgmString(PSTR(" M1")); break;
00268     case PROGRAM_FLOW_COMPLETED : printPgmString(PSTR(" M2")); break;
00269   }
00270 
00271   switch (gc.spindle_direction) {
00272     case 1 : printPgmString(PSTR(" M3")); break;
00273     case -1 : printPgmString(PSTR(" M4")); break;
00274     case 0 : printPgmString(PSTR(" M5")); break;
00275   }
00276 
00277   switch (gc.coolant_mode) {
00278     case COOLANT_DISABLE : printPgmString(PSTR(" M9")); break;
00279     case COOLANT_FLOOD_ENABLE : printPgmString(PSTR(" M8")); break;
00280     #ifdef ENABLE_M7
00281       case COOLANT_MIST_ENABLE : printPgmString(PSTR(" M7")); break;
00282     #endif
00283   }
00284 
00285   printPgmString(PSTR(" T"));
00286   printInteger(gc.tool);
00287 
00288   printPgmString(PSTR(" F"));
00289   if (gc.inches_mode) { printFloat(gc.feed_rate*INCH_PER_MM); }
00290   else { printFloat(gc.feed_rate); }
00291 
00292   printPgmString(PSTR("]\r\n"));
00293 }
00294 
00295 // Prints specified startup line
00296 void report_startup_line(uint8_t n, char *line)
00297 {
00298   printPgmString(PSTR("$N")); printInteger(n);
00299   printPgmString(PSTR("=")); printString(line);
00300   printPgmString(PSTR("\r\n"));
00301 }
00302 
00303  // Prints real-time data. This function grabs a real-time snapshot of the stepper subprogram
00304  // and the actual location of the CNC machine. Users may change the following function to their
00305  // specific needs, but the desired real-time data report must be as short as possible. This is
00306  // requires as it minimizes the computational overhead and allows grbl to keep running smoothly,
00307  // especially during g-code programs with fast, short line segments and high frequency reports (5-20Hz).
00308 void report_realtime_status()
00309 {
00310   // **Under construction** Bare-bones status report. Provides real-time machine position relative to
00311   // the system power on location (0,0,0) and work coordinate position (G54 and G92 applied). Eventually
00312   // to be added are distance to go on block, processed block id, and feed rate. Also a settings bitmask
00313   // for a user to select the desired real-time data.
00314 /*
00315   uint8_t i;
00316   int32_t current_position[3]; // Copy current state of the system position variable
00317   memcpy(current_position,sys.position,sizeof(sys.position));
00318   float print_position[3];
00319 
00320   // Report current machine state
00321   switch (sys.state) {
00322  //   case STATE_IDLE: printPgmString(PSTR("<Idle")); break;
00323 //    case STATE_INIT: printPgmString(PSTR("[Init")); break; // Never observed
00324     case STATE_QUEUED: printPgmString(PSTR("<Queue")); break;
00325     case STATE_CYCLE: printPgmString(PSTR("<Run")); break;
00326     case STATE_HOLD: printPgmString(PSTR("<Hold")); break;
00327    case STATE_HOMING: printPgmString(PSTR("<Home")); break;
00328     case STATE_ALARM: printPgmString(PSTR("<Alarm")); break;
00329     case STATE_CHECK_MODE: printPgmString(PSTR("<Check")); break;
00330   }
00331 
00332 
00333   // Report machine position
00334   printPgmString(PSTR(",MPos:"));
00335   for (i=0; i<= 2; i++) {
00336     print_position[i] = current_position[i]/settings.steps_per_mm[i];
00337 
00338     if (bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_REPORT_INCHES)) { print_position[i] *= INCH_PER_MM; }
00339 
00340     printFloat(print_position[i]);
00341     printPgmString(PSTR(","));
00342   }
00343 
00344   // Report work position
00345   printPgmString(PSTR("WPos:"));
00346   for (i=0; i<= 2; i++) {
00347 
00348     if (bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_REPORT_INCHES)) {
00349       print_position[i] -= (gc.coord_system[i]+gc.coord_offset[i])*INCH_PER_MM;
00350     } else {
00351       print_position[i] -= gc.coord_system[i]+gc.coord_offset[i];
00352     }
00353 
00354     printFloat(print_position[i]);
00355     if (i < 2) { printPgmString(PSTR(",")); }
00356   }
00357 
00358   printPgmString(PSTR(">\r\n"));
00359   */
00360 }
